Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2014 09:31AM BikerLee wrote: hey there - i'm flat and darn happy with it.  as a very active mom, professor, and so on, being flat is great.  i am an athlete, and i was an rather well endowed athlete before bc.  anyway...  i am very happy with flatness. one direction i'll also point you - if you are on Facebook, consider checking out "flat and fabulous" - amazing group...  diverse group of people struggling with these very decisions...  things i love about being flat?  i can jump up and jump around with my kid, without regard for my boobs. i can roll over in bed, without squashing my boobs... i can roll over a pothole on my bike... and there's no boob-quake... and more.  what's surprised me is how little it seems people even notice.  there are a handful of shirts i no longer wear... but there are a handful of my shirts that i think actually look BETTER without boobs!   i won't lie - i do miss my nipples, but recon doesn't change that....  i had fabulous nipples...   my family has been very supportive.   anyway - good luck! i hope you are able to come to a decision around which you feel a deep sense of peace.  flat was the decision that gave me that sense of peace...  so flat i am!
Posts.Title: Younger women who chose no reconstruction Allydp Erica

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2013 10:33PM BikerLee wrote: If chemo is definitely called for, is it possible to have chemo first? This lets a person really have time to make the most solid decision... AND lets you know if the chemo is effective against your tumor. Just a thought. I had chemo first, and I'm really grateful for how solid I felt about my bmx decision going into surgery. That gave me a sense of peace around that decision - a decision none of us is truly prepared to make... a decision none of us should have to make.  Sigh... Just my two cents.... Lee
Posts.Title: How did you decide on lumpectomy or mastectomy/ livingwithit IrishDancingMom

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2014 09:08AM BikerLee wrote: Hey BAU - love the handle, by the way… pretty darn funny! So, I'm a long time vegetarian hippy kind of an athlete… and I got cancer. I eat right, I exercise a ton, I drink a little too much beer (few a week)…  But I got cancer. Why?  People around me eat terribly, drink a ton, never exercise, and they don't get cancer. Why? Wouldn't it be nice if we could say this thing or that thing caused the cancer… Then we could tell everyone exactly what causes cancer and prevent a whole heck of a lot of disease. Bottom line is that some of the things we are exposed to, whether through our control or not, may contribute to developing cancer…  or may NOT…  We honestly don't know enough.   I used to heat my tea water in a carbonate plastic container - bpa city!  I grew up eating highly processed foods… There are things our grandmothers may have been exposed to that are known endocrine disruptors… and evidence shows effects in our grandmothers' granddaughters. How crazy is that???? What's my point?  There's no way to know WHY you got cancer. Even people who have tested positive for various cancer genes may never go on to develop cancer... while others do…   So, put that energy into facing FORWARD. You say you were an athlete? Why "WERE"? What did you love to do? Being active during chemo (which I assume is part of your treatment plan since you now have a port) is critical to reducing side effects and suffering.  I heard that time and time again. As a bike racer, my obvious exercise of choice is riding bikes. So, I did that every single day during chemotherapy….  Except for a couple of days of business travel (no access to a bike).  Some days were short and slow… but most days were just fine.  Was I racing? No… but I was active and moving and it really did make things better. I also worked and stayed socially active (except for a total of about two weeks, during which my counts were super low and the health care providers told me to avoid unnecessary exposures to people). As for the weight-gain-loss cycling…  This is a common struggle for former athletes… You are not alone in this. So… get active and stay active! Learn something new!  I learned how to skate ski and ice skate so that I have fun winter sports even though I still commute everywhere by bike… Turn your transportation into active transportation…  Do whatever it takes to return to that love of sport / action / movement.  And don't wait - do it now…   As for the port incision - I was exercising the next day. I kept the effort aerobic… but I was riding the next day. Ask your health care team about how long you need to wait before safely exercising…. It might be sooner than you think. I'm so sorry you're dealing with this in your 20s.  It sucks - no two ways about it. Hugs. Lee
Posts.Title: Beating myself up Bad_At_Usernames Dtowles

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2012 04:59PM BikerLee wrote: I would say that if you can choose one less drug with no additional risk of recurrence, so far as they know, choose one less drug.  The long term and short term side effects are significant.  So, if the outcomes are expected to be similar, choose the lesser of the two regimens, in my humble opinion. I assume the T is taxol. Is the C carboplatin or cytotoxin?  I also assume the A is andriamycin.... So, if you do TC - it's four cycles? If you do ACT - it's eight cycles? Four AC followed by four T? Whatever you choose, I wish you maximum effectiveness with a minimum of side effects!
Posts.Title: TC vs TAC? Ergirl Teakay

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2012 07:47AM BikerLee wrote: RoBo - sucky!!!! permanent alopecia???  I'm so sorry! Neuropathy - anyone doing any kind of chemo that has neuropathy as a potential side effect should consider adding GLUTAMINE as a supplement during chemo.  You can buy this as a powder... Take about 10 g and swirl it in water, and then drink up!  It doesn't have much taste, and it's actually made it through some clinical trials.  The upside is that it does not interfere with chemo but does reduce some pretty icky side effects, like mouth sores and NEUROPATHY!   So, ask your onco about adding it.  Mine was HAPPY to say YES!   A rather large container of glutamine powder runs about $25. I went through two containers.  I had minimal tingling in the very tips of my fingers and toes... but it was really quite minimal.  More like my toe tips and fingers tips just sort of felt weird.  I had the taxol stage before the AC stage, and that weird feeling was gone by the time I was done with AC, actually.  During AC, the glutamine made a difference with mouthsores.  I slacked off... and paid for it...  got back onto the glutamine wagon, and the mouthsores were much less severe.... No matter what - GOOD LUCK!!!!  May you have maximal effectiveness with minimal side effects... Lee Google scholar search:  glutamine chemotherapy or glutamine chemotherapy neuropathy etc... LINK to an article that talks about using glutamine... http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0305737203001336 There's a ton of info out there....
Posts.Title: TC vs TAC? Ergirl Teakay

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2012 07:53PM BikerLee wrote: Is it like keloidal tissue?  Some people just get that.  About 50% of my mastectomy scar is "thick" and the other 50% is "thin" - if that makes any sense.  I'd say that it feels like a piece of twine right in that scar - for around 10 or 12 cm on each side.  And the keloid part is dark pink and a little bit shiny.  The rest feels much more supple.  The twine has been softening up over the last month or so.  I put oil on the scar after every shower.  Based on images I have seen - I'd say I have fairly minor keloids, and I'm told that my scars look quite good. Does htat help at all?  I don't know.  It was the first thing that came to my mind when I read your post. Good luck. Lee
Posts.Title: Thickening of scar many Bugs

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2014 09:48AM - edited Apr 30, 2014 09:49AM by BikerLee good morning!  i had neoadjuvant chemo as well - complete pathological response, which meant no detectable cancer after it was all said and done.... yippee!!!!  with my tumor's triple negative status, that complete pathological response is a huge predictor of disease-free survival....  again - another yippee!   i noticed you said you've got what i "lovingly" referred to as pizza head.... and i've written a piece on this. my health care team did not give antibiotics for my horrid pizza scalp....  and i sort of took things into my own hands....  here's a lightly modified version of what i wrote on my blog about this very issue: Alopecia scalp care – OK – an ugly side of chemo hair loss can be horrible horrible ugly pizza head. And by ugly, I mean ginormous ugly looking white heads on your scalp! The things look painful and are painful. Not everyone gets them, but I sure as heck did! And there’s no way a person could tell me – oh – they aren’t really all that noticeable! The docs all told me to just leave my head open to the air. I just couldn’t do that because I found the acne to be so … well… embarrassing! They also said no hot showers! I love hot showers! They also said don’t rub your head when you dry it – just pat it dry!!!! NONE of these things helped even one tiny bit. So, I did some research… and combined things I found in order to come up with my own recipe for success. Lee’s two-step recipe for a smooth and acne-free chemo scalp. ONE: When you shower, use hibiclens (available at pharmacies - same stuff i used before my port installation surgery) on your head. Do not let hibiclens get into your eyes or ears. Use a dime amount in the palm of your wet hand… Before your head gets wet, rub that all over your head for around 15-30 seconds…. RINSE SUPER WELL! Your shower can be as hot or not hot as you prefer. TWO: After you shower and your scalp is dry, use a salicylic acid solution on your head. About a dime to nickel size amount in your palm – rub over your whole head… I believe that you are free to rub or pat your head dry. I like to rub because it just feels good. Then, Once totally try, wear whatever you like on your head. Viola! Within about one week, my horrid scalp acne had completely resolved, and I was once again willing to let the world see my bald head.  Lee Penn's totally acne-free and smooth bald head. (http://rleepenn.wordpress.com/2012/02/11/tips-for-surviving-chemotherapy/)

Posts.Title: Large hard lump Ally44 Labibaxo

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2012 07:40PM BikerLee wrote: Hope u don't mind a stage II weighing in here. I saw the subject line and instantly remembered my horrid horrid scalp acne. After receiving advice and instructions that turned out to be utterly useless.... No hot showers... No rubbing... No hats (yeah right).... I did this: When showering, use hibiclens (same stuff they had me use prior to surgeries) on your head. After showering, use a salicylic acid solution - around 2% solution - as can be found in solutions for acne treatment. I got mine at our health food store. I just put some in my palm and rubbed all over my head. Within days, I was sooooooo much better! And by better... I mean what a RELIEF! That scalp acne HURTS and is UGLY! I've recommended this regimen to others, and, so far, it's been 100% effective. I hope this helps you.... On top of everything else... Scalp acne? Really? Right? Anyway, I would say that if you don't see marked improvement within one week, then it might be something altogether different.... Good luck.... And scalp acne sucks (obviously)....
Posts.Title: Scalp sores Mzmerz Mzmerz

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2013 02:25PM BikerLee wrote: hi there - i had 12 taxol (with 4 carboplatins) and then 4 ac, and i had my last treatment in jan of 2012. so, i am now one and one-half years out. i don't think i had the joint pain like you're talking about... and i definitely am a bit different than i was before chemo... but...  well...  this past weekend, i did a 24 hour bike race, and i tied for third overall (including men and women).  there were 88 of us that chose to race solo, and i was one of those insane people.  the few other hundred people? they were smart - they were on TEAMS! that said - i'll probably do it again next year. it.gets.better. i promise.  there's no way i could have done this race solo one year ago.  no way.  at six months out, i was riding decently... but i was not nearly as strong as i am now...  at six months, i felt more optimistic and like things were going in the right direction.... i feel like the estimate of one year is spot on. that's when you really feel like - ah.... i'm coming back.   another thing to consider - are you dealing with symptoms of menopause? i was very sad to learn that my ovaries were fried by chemo - and that sudden chemo-pause was HARD!!!! i had insomnia and pretty much felt like everything sucked. i am actually being treated for that...  and that has helped tremendously with my general outlook on life and so on.... i hope that helps. lee
Posts.Title: How long until chemo affects wear off? nepenthes gailani

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2013 11:04AM BikerLee wrote: hi there - sorry  you're here.  i'm 43, and i finished up treatment a little more than a year ago (see below).  i have an 11 year old child, who's mostly awesome, except when kranky and hungry and/or tired. anyway...  i live in minneapolis, and here in minnesota, we have an organization called the angel foundation (not a religious organization).  it's specifically geared towards families with an adult facing a cancer diagnosis.  we went through their 6 week monday evening workshop / support group series, and our child gained a ton from it - not only being able to talk about cancer with other kids but also meeting some friends and getting to eat some good food.  he also goes to cancer camp in the summer - this year it's a six day long camp in northern minnesota - he's so excited. my point is this - there are resources out there for us - there are people who can help us navigate this diagnosis AS PARENTS.  the first and most important thing our children need to know is that they'll be okay.  no matter what happens, they will be cared for and they will be okay. the second thing they need to know is that they can't catch cancer - a lot of kids worry about this.  they cannot catch cancer. the third thing... they also need to know what's going on- at an age appropriate level.  you're probably 100% correct that your kids know something's up.  we started with - mama is sick... we don't know much yet...  and moved on from there. we did a day-long cancer retreat for families with the angel foundation, a couple of evening events, and that six week long series. in addition, he's attended day camp with the mn angel foundation, and he LOVED it... a ton!  and he will actually talk about cancer... and he continues to ask questions.  when he finds out someone has cancer... he comes right to me to ask questions about how that cancer is different - etc...  anyway, part of this is finding an active role for your children to play - this was something the social workers strongly suggested we all do. so, when you're tired or when you need to go to an appointment, each of your children can have a role to play, no matter how small. for one woman, it was hard for her to open car doors, so her child's role to play was opening car doors.  do you see what i mean?   resources like this are often advertised at our cancer centers.  sometimes, a social worker can help us find these resources.  i'm soooooo glad we found that one - the minnesota angel foundation - made a huge and positive difference for our family. being able to talk to other parents was huge. and my better half gained a ton too - one week, the caregivers and people with the actual diagnosis separated for the adult portion of the evening.... for example. the child gained a ton - he actually would talk about cancer with both of us after participating, and he seems to feel very comfortable with asking cancer related questions, which is also great.  sometimes, it's hard to hear those questions, and sometimes, i have no answers... but our lines of communication are open, and that's huge. i hope this helps. i'd be happy to email with you - about parenting issues etc...  it's hard... but it's doable. huge hug.... lee
Posts.Title: 43, Mother of 2 Young Boys and Scared! Tr8cyg DC197

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2012 07:18PM BikerLee wrote: i had a cold at the beginning as well - turned out to be no big deal at all.  phew!!!!  i was nervous too! i did make a habit of taking my temp about twice a day when i was feeling very cruddy...   later, when my infection fighters really took a nose dive, the nurses gave me some of the hand foam that they use in the infusion center.  i then had a strict foam in policy both at home and in my office.  i teach at a university and see many many students every day...  and i have a young child, who is quite generous with his germs....   anyway, i stayed, from the persepctive of chemo, quite healthy throughout the winter.  in minnesota, that's saying something! funny story though... my son had his birthday party right before i had my post-chemo bilateral mastectomy.  i was being very careful about hand washing and hand cleanliness in hopes of not having to deal with a delay in surgery.  anyway, as each child arrived, i put a pile of foam in each child's hand.  one mom drops her son and sees me foam her child in... and says - HEY - I WANT SOME!!!!  so, i was like... okay. sure.  and then.... SHE ATE IT!!!! on her way to her car, she ate the foam!!!!  my sweetie and i just looked at each other and wondered what kind of strange woman was she???? turns out, she thought we were strange for giving each child a palm full of whipped cream... but she loves whipped cream, so she was like, hey.. i want some.  whoa - did she get a surprise!!!!  i haven't tasted the foam in order to experience what she experienced... but... uhmm.... YUCK!?!?!?! good luck - hope you're feeling better soon....

This is the hardest time. But you'll find a ton of support here. STAY OFF THE INNERWEBS - they will not help you... Try your best to stay off the innerwebs - you can end up so very frightened by what you read ... Once you have more information, then focused research is super useful, but not until you have more information about your diagnosis. Hugs.

Posts.Title: here again sandrak1 Cary108

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2012 07:34AM BikerLee wrote: the surgeon who did my bmx also did my port, but i had chemo before surgery, so the port was placed as a separate procedure.  however, i had the port removed at the time of the bmx. i had a love hate relationship with my port.  it definitely made chemo easier...  but i didn't like the feel of it, to be honest.  but, i would totally get the port again.  i have one blown vein from a hand iv, and it bums me out.  all of my other veins are in good condition, and i doubt this would be true if i had not had the port. one thing to consider - when they do blood draws from the port, they have to waste the first syringe full of blood.  i got quite anemic with chemo, so i stopped having blood draws from the port and insisted on minimal volumes for every blood test possible.  for simple cbc checks, i did finger sticks.  for metabolic panel plus cbc, i did arm stick.  when my counts were low, i was having two blood tests per week (to determine whether a neupogen shot was warrented).   at the end of the day, one less anasthesia sounds like a good idea to me. however, if the surgeon is not comfortable doing the procedure, then i would not want it done by that surgeon.  they are directly accessing a major vein in your neck, so experience is something i would desire in the port-placement surgeon. it doesn't surprise me that the plastic surgeon hasn't done it.  but your breast surgeon probably has...   good luck - i hope things go smoothly and everything can be done in one surgery!

Posts.Title: I ran a frickin' Marathon!! KerryMac NancyD

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2013 04:00PM BikerLee wrote: this is the scariest time - no doubt about that. it does get easier - especially once you begin the treatment plan. it was exactly one month from the cancer call to the first chemo treatment for me. that month was HARD!!!! i echo the advice regarding talking to your health care team about help with anxiety and insomnia. i also had insomnia. i'd sleep from around 10p until around 1:30a or so... and then up for the day. i'd end up blogging or reading or whatever... then - i talked to the health care team about insomnia and anxiety, and they prescribed ambien and xanax... ambien sort of sucked - the sleep was weird... and i didn't like how i felt falling asleep... i'd sleep until around 3 or 4a, though... anyway, i took it a handful of times and never went back to it. xanax, on the other hand, was great. i took that at bedtime every night, and my mind would calm... and then i'd sleep for 5ish hours... and the sleep was good. each one of us is very difference, and different meds work for different people. some are able to meditate their way to decent sleep...me - not so much. my health care team basically said that if there's ever a time to go ahead and take meds... it's before and during treatment. so, i did. after treatment was done, i returned to my nearly no pill lifestyle. i hope that helps. the other thing that helped me a bunch was exercise. i worked out HARD during the pre-treatment stage... and then kept exercising through all of treatment. sure - there were days i was tired, and my exercise sessions were light and somewhat short... my exercise of choice was riding bikes, and i rode bikes every single day of treatment, with the exception of two days of a business trip. on those two days, i walked. the exercise helped me feel like i had some control. so, that's what i've got. i hope you are able to get some help... and get to treatment smoothly and quickly. good luck. lee

Posts.Content: May 29, 2012 03:19AM BikerLee wrote: if you use a clippers, you can make it short...  i think you don't want to cut it down to the skin in case you get an ingrown hair...  but, after a while, you'll be good to go on regular shaving.  i too was told that i should never use a blade again, even though i had only one node biopsied...  i usually, though, just use the hair clippers....  it's pretty easy, and it gets pretty short... and i never get ingrowns when i do it that way.  dunno if that helps...  my bmx was in feb, and i used the clippers like three ish weeks after.
Posts.Title: How long to wait to shave underarms after a mastectomy and SNB? Soyaandpepper MFalabella

Posts.Content: May 28, 2012 03:15PM BikerLee wrote: Asking for and receiving help are hard! But your good friend not only want but also NEED to help! So - a little coaching... Repeat after me - YES PLEASE THAT WOULD BE SO WONDERFUL THAT WOULD BE A HUGE HELP THANK YOU THANK YOU VERY MUCH And... If someone has said something like "let me know if there is something I can do..." which is the most vague thing.... Take it as a genuine offer of help. Yes, there are a few things that could help us very much. Would you be willing to have our children overnight on xxx date? (our son had an overnight the night before my bmx) Would you be willing to have my children for a short tme after school? (our son had one or two after school dates with the neighbors per week) Would you be willing to go to chemo with me? (my better half went with me every time but one, and a friend went that time) If you are worried about puking in your friend's car... How do you feel about your friend driving YOUR car? I rode my bike to every single chemo... And rode home... And I was totally fine. The one time that I was pukingly ill was after the fourth AC - I didn't get sick until HOURS later.... The anti-puke drugs they give you before the AC really do help... And should keep you good until you get home. Then, make sure you take the meds as the NURSES suggest. They know which to take when.... Do you have a tendency to get motion sick? Apparently, if you had a tendency to get motion sick, then your chances of feeling nauseous with AC are higher.... I do, and I did. But I adhered to the meds, and that made it better... Finally - I highly recommend that you take GLUTAMINE as a supplement during chemo.... For days 1-4, with chemo day being day zero, take 10 g swirled in water three times each day.... It will help with mouth sores and neuropathy and so on... For me, the one time I slacked off this supplement, I got horrid horrid mouth sores and had to have the magic mouthwash. If up I google GLUTAMINE and taxol or chemotherapy, you'll find a treasure trove of results... Including results from some clinical trials showing that GLUTAMINE is a good good thing during chemo.... Good luck... May your first infusion go smoothly - no surprises.... Oh - last bit of advice. If you are feeling really anxious, consider requesting ativan.... That there is a lovely little drug that just makes the whole experience less stressful.... Ad helps with nausea to boot!

Posts.Title: Is my condition severe? Need help Swastika mjm1

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2014 04:29PM BikerLee wrote: morning everyone!  i'm a huge bike rider and racer, and i was also worried about this... in the end, i was super fortunate and had only the sentinel node biopsy, but that doesn't necessarily put me into the clear for lymphedema risk... few thoughts, tho... 1)  sun protection - if you're wearing a sleeve, you've surely got good sun protection.  if  you're not wearing a sleeve, consider using "arm coolers" - very thin stretchy sleeves that one can buy in many different colors.  i use these much of the summer months, even when it's like 90 deg F outside.  i can soak them with water, which helps with body cooling...  i like them because sun screen, which can be great - don't get me wrong, interferes with the whole sweat process.  when riding long and hard, one needs the whole sweat process to be working...  so, i've been opting for cloth-based sunscreen in the form of arm coolers, and i've been very happy with the results. 2) position - when doing a long and challenging event, it's easy to forget to change positions... occasionally, sit up and move your arms... change your position on your bars...  can you ride hands-free?  if yes, then do so whenever the pace allows.  if your fit causes numbness in your hands or anywhere, really, get a proper bike fit.  make sure your position is not compromising your circulation. 3)  hydration hydration hydration - buff said. 4)  if you get into any kind of a crash - road rash must be attended to carefully and quickly.  we have a bigger risk of infection and so on, even without onset of lymphedema...  so, if you crash, get cleaned up asap... ICE ICE ICE!!!!  and so on...   5)  do self lymph massage a few times per day - especially on long endurance ride days...  there are several really great youtube videos that give good instructions for self lymph massage for post-mastectomy and node dissections...  i used to be quite anal about this...  maybe it had the hoped-for result... or maybe i just wasn't one of the unlucky ones with regard to lymphedema - who knows...  but i did self lymph massage regularly to position myself for the most success possible.   last - and most importantly - LOVE YOUR BIKE... keep it in good repair... keep a look out for wear on your tires...  do your abc check before every ride...  all to maximize your happiness on your bike but also prevent mechanicals that could lead to a mishap...  and ride ride ride... me?  during the "on" season, i ride anywhere between ten and twenty hours a week...  sometimes more...  i love riding - i use bikes for recreation and transportation and hauling things and people... i also race, and i love racing...  i race on road and off road... this year's new race venue for me is gravel racing... never done this, but it is HOT these days...   keep the rubber side down... lee ps - feel invited to pm me if you have questions... i'm happy to do my best to answer questions and so forth...
Posts.Title: Bicycling with LE...need advice simplelife4real kriserts

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2012 11:06PM BikerLee wrote: I am not stage IV, but I think my auntie (in law) is.  Three weeks ago, she had her annual mammo...  this week she had a mastectomy.  She has a spot on her lung that showed up on PET/CT, and she is waiting for bone scan results. I think the spot on her lung makes her stage IV, right?  Unless it turns out to be unrelated to breast cancer...   I called her yesterday, and I told her that if there is one person she can be all negative with - that'd be me.  I told her that she has to choose such people carefully.  So many expect the positivity to be the ONLY attitude... and we all have bad days, whether we're cancer patients or just regular people.  But, when we're cancer patients, people do not want to see krankiness or any other less than positive attitudes / feelings. I've offered to research anything she'd like (I'm at a University, so this is fairly easy for me to do). It was a pretty long phone call, actually.  She clearly wanted to talk...  so I feel like that was a good thing.  Beyond that - I'm not sure if there's much I can do. I think I'll send her a chemo care package - chemo is definitely coming soon. We're not terribly close - I mean - we're family... but I've only spent time with her around a dozen times.  I don't know her very well.  But, I want to be a source of support in whatever way is possible. So...  please share your advice!  No tidbit is too small nor too large. Thank you.

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2012 11:02AM BikerLee wrote: My auntie said she's definitely doing chemo - according to her docs.  Also, radiation.  Right now, she's at home healing from a radical mastectomy.  Yes - radical.  Also, she had a node biopsied, and that was positive.  So, during the mastectomy, they also did a full axiallary node dissection. I definitely would NOT send a care package without being sure. She gets her bone scan results probably a day or two from now. I hope hope hope that spot on her lung is NOT breast cancer.  I hope hope hope it sooooo very much.  She definitely had one positive node...     From her biopsies, I thought she would know her hormone statuses...  But, she does not. So, I'm just waiting with baited breath for those pathology results... hoping that there were clear margins and only negative nodes....  and I hope that bone scan comes back clean....    Thanks for your responses....
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2012 10:27PM BikerLee wrote: I know it's hard to NOT constantly give yourself a breast exam right now (chuckle a little at that one?), but stop touching your breasts.... Get an exam as soon as you can.... There are so many things that can make boobies bumpy, including totally not-scary things like fibrocystic disease and cysts and so on. In fact, most bumpy boobies turn out to just be bumpy boobies... So, try to take a deep breath.... Deep breath in..... Deep breath out.... And take this thing one step at a time. One.step.at.a.time. Hopefully, you'll get an appointment for super soon, and you'll have an ultrasound... Maybe a biopsy.... And then you'll have some answers. Now, take your hand off your boob! (did I catch you?) Seriously, I couldn't leave mine alone when I found my lump.... It was all I could do to not palpate it in public! Good luck... There's a lot of really good advice here.

Posts.Title: 18 years old IBC symtoms jeandavis jeandavis

Posts.Content: May 29, 2012 03:29AM BikerLee wrote: oh my gosh - that just sounds awful!  seems like loads of you are just suffering so. i now feel very very lucky. i have tightness, as if i am wearing a bra... i have some touch tenderness under my snb armpit... but my range of motion is good... and in general, i love being flat. one thing to consider - maybe you are dealing with axillary web syndrome (AWS)? i did get cording, but it's resolving and it didn't limit my range of motion much. i fall into that category of relatively thin... and i'm super active. i ended up in a clinical trial meant to study the prevalence of aws as well as how it progresses and resolves... the physical therapist in charge of it said that thinner women deal with aws more.  anyway, it feels like cords running from just below my armpit to about 1/3 along the underside of my arm - like guitar strings.  also, one of my tendons pops out and is kind of touch tender.   i wish i had answers - seems like few have good answers... i do know that it seems to hurt more if i don't move and if i don't sleep well.... good luck.... lee
Posts.Title: Significant pain three months post -BMX Wrongchick crystalphm

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2012 05:43AM BikerLee wrote: i'm also an athlete and had a bmx and have ZERO REGRETS! i love being braless. i love being flat. i love that i am symmetrical (nearly).... i do miss my nipples.  i wish i could have kept my nipples.  but the onc. surgeon did not like that idea at all. i was relatively well endowed (for an athlete)... and every thing is easier with out boobs.  and... no more upper back pain... ever! with unilateral, i'd worry about upper back pain, i think... good luck - this is a tough decision.  i was fortunate in that both oncs i worked with supported bmx and that i had chemo first, which gave me ample time before surgery.  my first gut reaction was bmx, and that never wavered. sorry you have to make this decision... it sucks.
Posts.Title: To be flat or uniboob, please help Frapp Lily55

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2013 07:28AM BikerLee wrote: here in minnesota, we have an organization called minnesota angel - it's not a religious organization but rather one specifically for families with kids in which an adult care giver is dealing with a cancer diagnosis.  this helped so very very much!!!!!  we attended a once weekly "facing cancer together" series, and we learned a ton during that epxerience... as well as met some simply fantastic people. they also fed us dinner each night! it really helped to talk to other parents about the realities of day to day during treatment... and to talk about what is appropriate for sharing at different ages. the social worker who led our discussion group (adults only during this portion - kids were in their own activities) said there are a few things that can really help. one - make sure they know they'll be cared for no matter what... and that's true. you'll still be able to care for them, whether you need some help to get it done or not.   two - they can each have a roll to play.  interestingly, one parent said she enlisted her young child to always open and close the car door for her - after her surgery, she couldn't manage the door.  this made the child feel like he was helping her and he took his "job" very seriously... he was like 3 or 4 at the time. another parent said her child's job was to refill her bottle of water...   there's a third one, but i'm blanking on it at the moment...  wait wait - i remember - they might be worried they can catch it... nope - you can't catch this.... those were the three big things.   another thing to consider - perhaps you can do some activities you don't normally do but that they enjoy.  for me, my child and i actually watched a few netflix movies together, something we simply don't do much of in our home....  that provided some nice quality time and special time and helped. we also drew together... and when i was feeling good, we rode bikes together etc...  the good times will outnumber the bad times!  i had one very rough cycle, but otherwise, the good times way outnumbers the bad.... in the evenings - i often did reading time with him - side by side reading time - he read his thing... and i usually started off reading mine... but then fell asleep... ha ha... he remembers that.  then, he'd go to his own bed to sleep when it was time.   we also had some friends drop dinner off a few times - that was wonderful... and friends invite our child for playdates and offer rides to hockey (i missed one game because i just couldn't manage to stand outside for two hours... he plays park hockey)...  say yes to offers of help....  and thank you...  even if you're feeling okay or "not that bad" ... we all only have so many matches to burn, and if your children have the opportunity to go do something they want to do and it gives you some precious rest time.... say yes. and lastly... you'll manage. it's manageable.  it sucks, but it's manageable. and we're moms. so we simply get er done when we have to, right?  OK - one more lastly... hand hygene!  we had a pretty darn strict policy of hand washing while i was on the chemo.  when our son came home from school - wash hands now! when a friend came over - wash hands now! after eating - wash hands now! after blowing a nose - wash hands now!  we also had some hand foam, which we used a lot of (less drying - it was winter in minnesota, after all)...  i actually got fewer colds on chemo than i normally do in winter in minnesota...  success!!!!  number one thing you can do is keep yoru hands and your children's hands washed up regularly! ok - good luck... parenting through chemo sucks... but it is doable - even more doable if you have a bit of help...  but doable nonetheless. hope this helps a little. lee ps - consider using glutamine as a supplement to prevent some of the side effects - nueropathy in particular - you can buy this as a powder - mix a rounded tablespoon in a cup of water - swirl and drink up!!!! three times a day for the first several days after each treatment.  of course, ask your oncology team before deciding, but i am convinced it helped me... and minimizing side effects makes this whole thing even a bit more manageable...  you know?
Posts.Title: Mother of 3 - starting chemo 7/24...how do I do this? Jserenityb0413 debbiema

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2012 10:43PM BikerLee wrote: totally a personal decision.... for me - no way would i stop working.  but, i have a flexible job.  i did take off a half-day for each infusion, and the best infusion day was either wednesday or thursday - afternoons highly preferred.  then, weekends were for feeling better. the taxol portion - no problem... occassionally needed to rest for a half hour or so (i.e., could do that over lunch)...  but really, no problem.  everything was manageable. the ac portion - the first two were alright... but the third and fourth were awful.  i ended up working half-days for a few days after #3 and half-days for a full week after #4.  then, things started improving improving improving.  and, from what i gather, rads are a breeze compared to chemo.  i had bmx and no rads...   but my schedule was opposite of yours... and my taxol portion was harsh - included an experimental drug and carboplatin every fourth infusion. so....   questions.... do you have to decide now?  can you choose to start unpaid leave if chemo turns out to be super rough for you? is it possible for you to be part-time employed during your "unpaid leave?"  perhaps in a related position or something like that?   are you active now?  my docs all were very insistent that i maintain as high an activity level as possible.  i did - i rode my bike every single day... and i nearly always reported fewer side effects than they expected...    consider using glutamine - this helps with preventing mouth sores and neuropathy and a few other side effects.  google glutamine and chemotherapy... there are a few articles about the results of clinical trials using this as a supplement during chemo.... and the results were impressive.  the one time i neglected to use it... i suffered...  it was during the ac portion, and i got horrid horrid mouthsores.... good luck - this is not an easy decision to make...  suppose you could do the whole list pros and cons thing...  one thing work did for me, i think, was just make the time go faster. i've never been good at just staying at home... and chilling...  this is not in my skillset.  so, the above is from that perspective.

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2014 12:05AM - edited Apr 24, 2014 12:07AM by BikerLee ask if you can have it removed during recon! i had mine removed with my double mastectomy, which meant one less incision to heal.   it was earlier than my care team wanted it removed, but it really did annoy me, and i wanted to go into recovery with the most optimistic attitude possible - hoping to never need one again.  my health care team was supportive of my decision...  and - i was glad to have it for chemo and glad to see it go soon thereafter! good luck!

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2012 03:23PM BikerLee wrote: One possibility is to get more exercise... Counterintuitive perhaps? Exercise can help your body just relax so that you can get sleep... Also, it will help you feel a little more energetic while you're awake. For me, Xanax is my go-to for insomnia, which I have had since dx in July.  I really miss sleeping like a baby... I used to be such a great sleeper!  Now, it's hit or miss... More miss when I don't get exercise.  Less miss when I do get exercise.  Definitely not regular. Sigh....
Posts.Title: CAN NOT SLEEP...UGH!!!! lanagraves Makratz

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2013 07:37PM BikerLee wrote: so... i just recently - sort of by accident - put capsaicin containing stuff on my mastectomy scars ... and the delightful result has been the low level pain that i've just sort of dealt with is .... gone. i think i had sort of just gotten used to it, but the absence of that low level pain has been ... lovely. before you think about doing it - call her health care team and ask about options... PAIN SUCKS and does not help one heal up. and ask about using capsaicin containing stuff (cream, ointment, etc...)... cuz wouldn't it be great if she could use something that doesn't involve taking a drug? turns out, there's a crazy bunch of bike racers out there (i'm one of them) that race in mud and snow and sand in cold weather. we use this stuff called embrocation. i recently one this little pot of capsaicin containing embrocation at a race, and i put some on my scars... and it's been a good little discovery. in case you're curious... the company name is donkey label and the embrocation is "medium" .... i really like this stuff, and it also moisturizes! and i happen to really like the way it smells. also, pharmacies carry capsaicin containing creams and such as well. she might have to wait a little bit before applying something directly onto her scars, but it might prove effective on her back where she has no scars. i had those weird sensations like what you describe - and phantom nipple sensations too... even if she has to wait a couple more weeks, consider trying it out once she's cleared for application of stuff onto her scars. word of warning - capsaicin is the stuff that makes hot peppers hot... it's also a main ingredient in pepper spray... so - don't get it in your (or her) eyes! i've accidentally done that... ooops. good luck.
Posts.Title: In alot of PAIN !!!! lillywa lillywa

Posts.Content: May 16, 2014 02:33PM BikerLee wrote: no no - there were... i liked the feeling of hot water on my bald scalp...  and i loved wearing my various cycling caps without regard for hat head.  and i dropped a bunch of weight and liked how i fit into my clothes.  i also liked the pre-chemo cocktail - ativan and benadryl gave me quite a high - lasted about 20  minutes... them BAM - nap time.
Posts.Title: Do we do silver linings here? boobieprized tangandchris

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2014 07:11PM - edited Mar 24, 2014 07:11PM by BikerLee i had carbo with my taxol - i was in a clinical trial that also included an experimental drug during this stage. yeah - the carbo are a bit harder than the taxol only weeks, and your blood counts will drop down a bit further, but i really did find it quite doable. and yeah - i've read that research, and it's pretty darn convincing, i've got to say. so... that leads me to my piece of advice - GLUTAMINE - ask about adding this as a supplement to your routine during the 12 weeks of carbo...  it's been shown to reduce neuropathy, and i adhered to it carefully during all 14 weeks ( i had two delays)...  i had very little neuropathy...  i don't know if glutamine helped that happen, but the stuff i've read (in the scientific literature) suggests it can really help. so - if your care team approves... you can buy this as a powder at most health food stores. you take a rounded spoonful - swirl it in a small cup of water... and drink up. it really doesn't taste like much, so it's easy to tolerate.  you do this three times each day for the first 3 days after each cycle.  so, infusion monday.... glutamine tues, wed, and thurs. i hope that helps.  was ac very hard for you? i did have neupogen a bunch of times... but the experimental drug i was on added to the drop in blood counts... i knew others who did not require the nuepogen.  if you're currently getting neulasta, which i had with ac... well, i found neupogen much much easier. by the way, if you have to get those shots, they sting a lot less when the fluid is allowed to come up to room temperature.... had a bunch that HURT .... and then had a difference nurse say  ... let's wait a few minutes before i administer this... why - i asked... oh - she said - hurts loads less when it's room temp.  ooooohhhhh.... and that little tidbit made all the subsequent shots far less sucky. good luck good luck good luck!!!!! ps - edited to add - nausea was MUCH LESS with taxol carbo than with AC... and by much less... I MEAN SOOOOOO MUCH LESS.. don't know if you;re struggling with that.
Posts.Title: Adding Carbo onto ACT…what can I expect? Allydp SpecialK

Posts.Content: May 13, 2012 05:35PM BikerLee wrote: Dear Stormy and everyone here. No.... I don't understand.  I....don't....understand.... period. This rant does NOT piss me off - not even a teensy eensy bit!  I'm so glad I read it, even as my heart is aching for every woman here. My heart has been aching all day as we were meant to hang out with some of our friends today - at a big parade here in Minneapolis- the May Day parade.  Alas, the mom of the family ended up in the hospital Friday night.  She has stage IV bc.  My better half and I both feel we cannot even begin to imagine... and hope we never have to experience the stage iv reality. I don't know if it is okay for me to post here.  I think this is a GREAT post for people to read.  It never ceases to surprise me when someone says something particularly insensitive or even just down right stupid.  Yet, what training do we get for talking about these issues?   I hope this post helps me be a better friend to my stage iv friends (breast cancer and other cancers). Hugs to all - I hope you have a peaceful afternoon. And Happy Mother's Day to the moms! Lee
Posts.Title: No, you don't understand... Stormynyte Reneepals
